publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: However, let us return to our box. It is of pure gold, a flat oblong chased and engraved in a very rude and aboriginal manner, as represented in the plate, and evidently must have been an antique, even when in Swift's possession. On the top (No. 1) is a very grotesque representation of an Irish wolf dog, under an oak tree, and on the reverse, (No. 2) of another dog and an eagle──all of them symbols of ancient Ireland. Inside the lid are the following doggrel lines, which are highly characteristic of “The Dean,” and a sample of that queer Anglo-Latin in which he delighted to bandy puns with Sheridan and Delany:──

Y51C#4YA 1 “From Churchman scribbler wit, a wit's a fool Y51C#4YA 2 “To a Lord; recte dictum, if such the rule;──Y51C#4YA 3 “When Peerages to men are given,Y51C#4YA 4 “Few like yours would appertain to Heaven:Y51C#4YA 5 “Concordia discors I have written,Y51C#4YA 6 “But with a cacoethes scribendi I am smitten;Y51C#4YA 7 “The box may be metal's basest dross;Y51C#4YA 8 “If you lose it, the less the loss;Y51C#4YA 9 “And though new it now appears,Y51C#4YA 10 “D──L──Y's mother used it many years.”Y51C#4YA
